name: Grenoble
fun_fact: Fun fact: Grenoble has the world's first urban cable car (1934), nicknamed 'Les Bulles' (the bubbles) for its iconic spherical glass cabins that look like floating eggs. It whisks you 260 meters up to the Bastille fortress in 5 minutes, and on foggy days you rise above a stunning sea of clouds. Over 14 million people have ridden it since 1934

hero_dishes.name: Gratin Dauphinois
hero_dishes.description: Thinly sliced potatoes baked in cream and milk until golden and bubbling - NO cheese in the authentic version (that's gratin savoyard). Creamy interior, crispy top, infused with garlic and nutmeg
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in the Dauphin√© region surrounding Grenoble, this is one of France's most argued-over dishes. Purists insist: no cheese, no eggs, only cream, potatoes, and garlic. Adding cheese starts regional wars. The dish was supposedly created in 1788 in Gap (south of Grenoble) but Grenoble claims it as their soul food
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Le Gratin Dauphinois restaurant (Grenoble train station area, named after the dish - ‚Ç¨10-15), La Table Ronde (since 1739, one of France's oldest restaurants)

hero_dishes.name: Ravioles du Royans
hero_dishes.description: Tiny square pasta pockets (smaller than a postage stamp) filled with Comt√© cheese, fresh herbs, and sometimes spinach. Served in cream sauce, browned butter, or in soup
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in the Royans region near Grenoble in the 1870s by a innkeeper's wife. These delicate ravioli are so small you need 20-30 per portion. Traditionally made with local Comt√© and parsley. Le Gratin Dauphinois sources theirs from Les Grands Goulets - 100% artisanal from La Chapelle-en-Vercors
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Le Gratin Dauphinois (artisanal from Vercors), La Table Ronde (traditional preparation), Les Halles Sainte-Claire market (fresh to cook at home)

hero_dishes.name: Saint-Marcellin Cheese
hero_dishes.description: Small round soft cow's milk cheese from nearby Is√®re - creamy, slightly tangy, with a wrinkled rind. When ripe, it's almost liquid inside
hero_dishes.origin_story: Made in the Dauphin√© since the 15th century, this cheese was supposedly saved King Louis XI's life when he tried it after a hunting accident. Once made with goat milk, now cow. Best eaten at room temperature when it's so ripe you need a spoon. Le Gratin Dauphinois serves it roasted with honey and walnuts
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Le Gratin Dauphinois (roasted with honey and walnuts), Les Halles Sainte-Claire market, any fromagerie in Grenoble

hero_dishes.name: Caillette de la Mure
hero_dishes.description: Savory meatballs made from pork, Swiss chard, spinach, and herbs, wrapped in caul fat. Eaten cold as a snack or warm with salad
hero_dishes.origin_story: A specialty from La Mure (south of Grenoble), these rustic Alpine meatballs date to peasant cooking. The caul fat (cr√©pine) keeps them moist. It's nose-to-tail eating before that was trendy - using every part of the pig. Traditionally eaten by farmers during harvest
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Le Gratin Dauphinois (home-cooked regional dish), traditional boucheries in Grenoble, March√© de l'Estacade outdoor market

signature_drinks.name: Chartreuse Liqueur
signature_drinks.description: Bright green or yellow herbal liqueur made by Carthusian monks near Grenoble since 1737. The recipe of 130 herbs is a secret known only to two monks. Intensely herbal, 55% alcohol
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Green Chartreuse (stronger, 55%) as a digestif, Yellow Chartreuse (sweeter, 40%) as an aperitif. Mix with tonic for a 'Chartreuse and tonic.' The monastery is in the Chartreuse mountains just north of Grenoble - you can visit but monks won't reveal the recipe. Serve ice-cold

signature_drinks.name: Alpine Wines from Savoie
signature_drinks.description: Crisp white wines from nearby Savoie region - Jacqu√®re, Altesse, Roussette. Light, mineral, perfect with cheese and mountain food
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with raclette, fondue, and gratin dishes. Grenoble sits at the gateway to the Alps, so Savoyard wine culture dominates. Drink young and chilled, never aged. These wines taste like melted snow and alpine flowers

food_culture_notes: Grenoble sits surrounded by three mountain ranges - it's the gateway to the French Alps and winter Olympic history (1968 Olympics)
Les Halles Sainte-Claire market is the heart of local food culture - covered market with regional specialties
The gratin dauphinois vs. gratin savoyard debate (cheese or no cheese) can end friendships in this region
La Table Ronde (1739) is one of the oldest continuously operating restaurants in France
